bibl.title: Letter from William G. Harrison to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [1929]

div1.p: Harrison thanks Emilie Lawrence Reed for donating her husband's letter. He inquires if she has anything else she would like to contribute to the Vanderbilt University Medical School Museum.

div1.head: Letter from William G. Harrison to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [1929]
div1.opener:
VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY
SCOOOL OF MEDICINE
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE
Bham Ala.
904 Empire Bldg.
WILLIAM GROCE HARRISON, M.D.
LECTURER IN HISTORY OF MEDICINE
My dear Mrs Reed:
div1.p:
Please accept my cordial & sincere
thanks for the gracious letter & more especially
for this highly prized one of your husband.
It will become a centre from which will
radiate enthusiasm & inspiration for many
young medical men. They will read of his
work -- see his on handwriting -- will
understand his Scientific poise, will vision
his love for mankind & will appreciate that
he was an affectionate father, a loyal,
appreciation husband & a real man. It will
bless many! The faculty of our school will
later send you an expression of their appre-
ciation. I hope you will fully understand the
value of these things to a museum frequently
by young Doctors- It meant far more than
to have them in a general museum
where the lay man views them, is distracted
by a thousand other things I rarely understand. If you
have a pen, a thermometer, an instrument
an article of clothing, shoes, cap, desk, chair
or any object you could spare us I shall
greatly appricate it. At present I live in
Bham Ala. but shall go to Nashville each
Thurs. for the school session to teach
VANDERBILT UNIVERSITY
SCOOOL OF MEDICINE
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE
WILLIAM GROCE HARRISON, M.D.
LECTURER IN HISTORY OF MEDICINE
The History of Medicine & in the mean time am collect-
ing such material as I can to illustrate the
development of medicine, in America -- more
especially trying to instil an appreciation of the
lives & spirit prompting our best men.

Many, many years ago I was c your husband
for Several afternoons while he was working at
Hopkins & I especially recall a walk living three
miles thru the snow to hear Dr Kelly talk on the
“History of Medicine”. His was a noble spirit! I
believe earnestly hope many young Doctors may be
stimulated thru his work. It shall be my
joy to assist in that direction. With best wishes
always for you & your children
